comment.body:
> I may miss some other important places.

Well, it's a public API so we can't know all places but have to assume (and support arbitrary) usage.

> What do you think about these possibilities? 

I very much like option 2: a) It only adds code in case "OQS_EMBEDDED_BUILD" is set, b) only impacts users calling `OQS_randombytes_switch_algorithm` with this option set (i.e., no present users) and c) adds a warning for the unwary. So would you please add this? Please also include a warning as per the above in the comment documentation of `OQS_randombytes_switch_algorithm`.

pull_request.title: Add support for Zephyr RTOS
pull_request.body:
Hi everybody,

This PR adds support for the [Zephyr RTOS](https://github.com/zephyrproject-rtos/zephyr), so liboqs can be used as a module (see [here](https://docs.zephyrproject.org/latest/develop/modules.html)). 

The main changes to the existing library code are focussed on the CMake build environment to enable the library to be built with the Zephyr SDK. All changes should not influence existing builds outside the Zephyr environment. (However, some changes also improve the integration of liboqs directly in a CMake-based project without installing it system-wide.) 

One bigger source code change is related to random number generation. Zephyr doesn't support any of the currently present RNG interfaces. To be most flexible, I added a generic `OQS_USE_EXTERNAL_RNG` option (disabled by default). In this case, an externally defined method `OQS_randombytes_external()` must be present during link time, which is then used to obtain random data. For Zephyr, I implemented that method to generate random data using their RNG interface. 

The main Zephyr integration is all contained in the new `zephyr` folder in the root directory (common practice for Zephyr modules to have this folder). In that directory, there is a custom `CMakeLists.txt` to integrate the existing CMake infrastructure into Zephyr. Furthermore, a Kconfig file is provided to configure the build (and especially the algorithm selection). Finally, the new `OQS_randombytes_external` method is implemented in a small C source file here. 

As this is my first PR for this project, I'm not sure if the changes are upstreamable in the current form. But I'm looking forward to your feedback.

Kind regards,
Tobi

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.body:
> So would you please add this? Please also include a warning as per the above in the comment documentation of `OQS_randombytes_switch_algorithm`.

I updated the commits to incorporate option 2 and added the warning. This should indeed be the best solution without changes to existing users. 

I also did a small cleanup in `rand.c` regarding all the different `OQS_randombytes_system` implementations that are present. Hope that is ok.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ if(CMAKE_C_COMPILER_ID MATCHES "Clang|GNU")
     add_compile_options(${OQS_OPT_FLAG})
 
     # If this is not a dist build we also need to set the OQS_USE_[EXTENSION] flags
-    if(NOT ${OQS_DIST_BUILD})
+    if(NOT ${OQS_DIST_BUILD} AND NOT CMAKE_CROSSCOMPILING)
comment.body:
The `try_run()` command inside `gcc_clang_instrinsics.cmake`  doesn't properly use the provided compiler flags and therefore can't produce a working executable using some embedded toolchains (e.g. the Zephyr one, but also applies to other toolchains). In this case, CMake fails and compilation is impossible. 

After the `try_run()` call, all CPU features have been disabled either way for cross compilation. Hence, I disabled the execution of the file completely for cross compilation.

comment.body: I'm absolutely not sure I like this API design: It doesn't seem idempotent (what if someone calls this twice, before calling `restore`?) and creating state in the library. What about returning here an opaque structure/pointer and taking this as parameter in the restore below instead?

pull_request.title: Test against all 100 KAT values
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

Add functionality to test against all 100 NIST KAT values.

- [x] Extend the `kat_kem` and `kat_sig` programs to generate all 100 KAT values
- [x] Collect SHA256 hashes for the extended KAT values
- [x] Create a Python script analogous to `test_nistkat.py` to run all 100 tests
- [x] Integrate the tests into a CI workflow

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

Fixes #1418 

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

repo.name: liboqs

comment.body:
One could do that, but I believe it would require either (1) "exporting" the `AES256_CTR_DRBG_ctx` structure so that it can be used by the test programs or (2) duplicating the definition of said structure in each test program that requires it (currently only `kat_kem` and `kat_sig`). Both of those are OK, I guess, but I don't think that the required "carving up" of the NIST DRBG code would be worth it: I doubt there's any use case that will require successive "save" calls without a "restore", and there is already state stored to enable the NIST DRBG.

I'd personally rather not even make the "save" and "restore" functions part of the API, but it seems to be the only clean(ish) way to make them accessible to our test programs...
